title: My desire to write is incredibly strong, matched only by my fear of somehow failing at it. How do you overcome this sort of resistance? - Quora

response.answer_text: What do you mean by failing. As I see it there are two possibilities. Please correct me if it is something else. First. Fear that you will not produce anything that is any good. Solution. Write every day. Write even if you produce rubbish. I have produced what I thought was rubbish because I had a target for that. I filed it away in my own internal slush pile. One day I had nothing to take to my writers group so I took something from my slush pile. They liked it. If that doesn’t convince you to right every day read On Writing (King). Second. Fear that people will not like your writing enough for you to make money out of it. Solution. You do not want to be a writer. You want to be rich. Or a celebrity. Or both. Writers do not write because it will make them rich. Very few writers become rich. Writers write because they have something inside themselves they need to get out. A musician must make music, an artist must paint, a poet must write, if he is to be ultimately at peace with himself(Maslow)

There is no special trick about writing and succeeding at it. The best thing, I would say is to first learn something well so you can always make a living. As for the scientific fields, any of them requires a long schooling and an intense application. If you're made for it nothing could be better. In the long run you will have to come to your own conclusion. The arts, which probably offer man more satisfaction, are uncertain. It is difficult to make a living. If I had my own life to lead over I presume I would still be a writer but I am sure I would give my first attention to learning how to do things directly with my hands. Nothing gives quite the satisfaction that doing things brings. The thing of course, is to make yourself alive. Most people remain all of their lives in a stupor. The point of being a writer is that you may live. Above all, try to remain humble. Smartness kills everything.

Playing Devil's advocate:Why would your desire to write be so incredibly strong? After all, you’re not very good at it. If you do it, you’ll be humiliated and everyone will laugh at you. While everyone is laughing, you won’t be paying attention and will absentmindedly walk into heavy traffic on a highway and break your hand and not be able to write anymore. You’ll get an award for the World’s worst writer and be exiled to Elba where even Josephine won’t cry for you.…. For God’s sake, and for the sake of humanity, PLEASE, throw away all your pens, paper, computer and don’t ever write again.…. And what do you mean by “somehow fail.” You’re just not that good.…. However, if you’re willing to sell your soul to the Devil, you can succeed easily without really trying. Just start a few wars, and write about it. Guaranteed success — so don’t worry about it so much. The Borg are here too: “Resistance is futile.”

I think I understand your problem. Take one step at a time, and stop worrying about your punctuations and grammar and all that jazz and just start writing. If you have found your rhythm, do not break the flow. You should wait at least until the next day to edit your writing. Look at it this way, do we filter our thoughts? No. But we have all been in a situation where we wished we could take back something we spoke. Spoken words cannot be retrieved. Now let’s see how this compares to writing. Think of writing as thinking. Our thoughts are raw and potent, with no filter. Similarly, when it comes to writing, just write. Once you have finished writing, you can choose to show it to others. If you don’t feel like it, you can stash it and move on to the next piece. No matter what, just begin by taking that first step. Set incremental goals. The first sentence, first paragraph, first page, and so on. I wish you all the best.

The simple answer is to practice. You will fail at the beginning, just like how you would fail at any difficult skill the first time you try. Just know that there are successful writers who started off as bad writers but got better, and you can too. I’ve never done a cartwheel, but I’ve seen that other people can, so with practice, I know I could eventually do it too. You can become a successful writer by failing at it a hundred times and succeeding on the hundred and first time.

You will fail at it. You will fail over and over. Until . . . you don’t fail. This is what’s called “normal” for this sort of activity. The more you practice your craft the better you get at it. The faster you want to advance in your craft, the more you should practice it. Yes it’s difficult. Yes it’s work. There are no shortcuts, there are no magic bullets. There’s only perseverance and work. Go to the I Ching, toss the yarrow stalks. You will get “Perseverance furthers.” Grit your teeth, put your head down.

My art teacher in high school never allowed us to say the word “can't”. That includes fear. Do not allow fear keep you from doing what you are meant to do. That applies to anything in life. Write a journal. See how it goes. Find your voice. Someday you will decide what you want to do with it. Don't fear failure. The best things are learned from failure. As babies we fall a lot until we walk.
